posts.name: Martin Terra
posts.cooked:
RFE: Dual Security Mode Proposal for Signal

Feature Description

Signal should introduce two security modes to enhance usability while preserving privacy:

  1. Casual Security Mode

    • Automatically syncs message histories across linked devices (e.g., phone, tablet, desktop)

    • Ideal for everyday, less sensitive chats such as with family or friends

    • Maintains end-to-end encryption while prioritizing user-friendliness

  2. Full Security Mode

    • Retains Signal‚Äôs current high-security approach, with no automatic message history syncing

    • Suited for sensitive conversations, such as business or private matters

    • Ensures maximum privacy by storing data locally

Users could set a default mode and choose specific modes for individual conversations or groups. This would provide the best of both worlds: convenience where it matters most and uncompromised security where it‚Äôs needed.

Background

There appears to be no existing forum request proposing exactly this ‚Äúcasual vs. full‚Äù security model, and no official roadmap addressing it. Most requests focus either on advanced security features or general usability improvements. For example, one recent suggestion was a ‚Äútop secret‚Äù group mode that enforces stricter privacy options.

Other messengers have already implemented a similar concept. Telegram offers cloud chats by default and end-to-end encrypted ‚ÄúSecret Chats‚Äù for sensitive use. WhatsApp offers encrypted backups as an opt-in feature. These demonstrate a practical hybrid approach, where convenience is the default and stronger encryption is available on demand.

Signal‚Äôs all-or-nothing model is excellent for protecting privacy, but it also creates barriers for everyday users who expect message sync across devices and a seamless experience. This proposed dual-mode feature would balance these needs, making Signal more accessible without compromising its core values.

Benefits

  • Improved Usability: Casual mode enables familiar features like message syncing, aligning with user expectations for modern messaging apps

  • Increased Adoption: Reduces friction for new users, expanding Signal‚Äôs appeal to a wider audience

  • Customizable Security: Users can choose the appropriate security level per conversation, combining convenience with control

  • Competitive Edge: Combining usability and privacy gives Signal a distinctive advantage over apps like WhatsApp and Telegram

  • Privacy Education: In-app guidance on mode differences can help users make informed security choices

  • Let‚Äôs make Signal the go-to app for everyone: Let‚Äôs make Signal the go-to app for everyone, not just privacy purists

Implementation Notes

  • Casual mode must retain end-to-end encryption to maintain Signal‚Äôs privacy standards

  • Provide clear, intuitive settings for selecting and switching security modes

  • Include optional tutorials to help users understand which mode best fits their needs

In summary, this proposal encourages Signal to offer a more flexible messaging experience. By introducing both casual and full security modes, Signal could improve usability and attract more users‚Äîwithout compromising the trust it has built. This simple enhancement would provide the best of both worlds, helping Signal stay true to its mission while becoming more practical for everyday communication.

Thanks for considering this!

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
If end-to-end encryption is opt-in, then it‚Äôs as good as not being encrypted at all e.g. Telegram.

You can already sync history with linked devices; unlimited for text and 45 days for media.

posts.name: Martin Terra
posts.cooked: That‚Äôs a misunderstanding. End to end encryption is supposed to be always used.

Exactly. And if you want to draw the parallel to opt-in encrypted backups (singular opt-in feature), then there are already a lot of choices here. Signal has a bunch off settings where you can choose how much privacy you want (e.g. usernames, discoverability/visibility, sync history or not, etc.).

The history transfer is optional and it is not complete in terms of media for technical reasons, not for privacy specifically.

posts.name: Martin Terra
posts.cooked:
The issue is not about having choices, but making Signal the go-to messaging for everyone, by making it as user friendly as the others are, when user opts to share messages more broadly across their devices (could be a new default).

The purpose of this RFE is to fix those ‚Äútechnical reasons‚Äù that currently prohibit the history transfer, and make it a default option for newbie users.

The rationale behind the current implementation is explained in this blog post (emphasis by me).

Signal Messenger

A Synchronized Start for Linked Devices

With Signal on Desktop and iPad, you can link your primary Android or iOS account with another device, letting you check and respond to messages in both places or conduct video meetings and calls from the comfort of a bigger screen. Signal‚Äôs upcoming...

All of your data in Signal is end-to-end encrypted. We don‚Äôt have access to your message history (or your contacts, groups, stories, profile avatars, or anything else). We go out of our way to know as close to nothing as possible about you and your data. This means that synchronizing your messages is complicated. Apps that don‚Äôt use end-to-end encryption have it easy: if the server has an unencrypted copy of all of your messages, every new linked device can just ask the server to send a copy of all of the stored messages. And bingo, everything is in sync! Plenty of unencrypted messengers operate this way ‚Äî probably even ones you‚Äôve used before. And while this is simple, these applications fail the mud puddle test. Meaning, they have access to your intimate communications and media in plaintext, allowing you to retrieve and sync your messages without your old device or any decryption keys, at the cost of their storing your communications history.

We‚Äôre not like that. We‚Äôre not willing to compromise on privacy, and so we need a way to transfer your history between devices without leaking any of your data to Signal or anyone else.

posts.name: Martin Terra
posts.cooked: Sure, but let users opt in for this instead where users feel they need it. Don‚Äôt be a ‚Äúbig brother‚Äù. If more people adopt Signal it is better for security and users overall, a greater good. The ideal is the foe of the feasible. From implementation perspective there can be different protocol for synchronizing messages where it is opted for.

Signal strives to strike balance between usability and security. As much as I don‚Äôt like ‚Äúas few options as possible‚Äù design philosophy, where security is at stake, it‚Äôs correct approach. Offering strict and ‚Äúrelaxed‚Äù security modes would give users more occasions to ‚Äúshoot themselves in the foot‚Äù.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
MartinTerra:

The issue is not about having choices, but making Signal the go-to messaging for everyone, by making it as user friendly as the others are

Signal is already user-friendly, so much so that my 70 year-old grandmother set it up herself. Signal was literally designed for that exact scenario i.e. you can install and set it up in a few minutes and it‚Äôs just a messaging app, but in the background it‚Äôs also more secure than every other messaging app available. Nobody has to know what keys are or how end-to-end encryption works; it‚Äôs just there and always on all the time.

MartinTerra:

by making it as user friendly as the others are, when user opts to share messages more broadly across their devices

I think you‚Äôre talking about syncing history across devices again, and that already happens when you link them. It‚Äôs been the default for at least a month at this point. Most people won‚Äôt seek that functionality though. Smartphones are the primary way people interact with everything.

MartinTerra:

Sure, but let users opt in for this instead where users feel they need it. Don‚Äôt be a ‚Äúbig brother‚Äù.

Default end-to-end encryption isn‚Äôt ‚ÄúBig Brother‚Äù. It‚Äôs actually the opposite: keeping users safe from Big Brother. And that can take different forms from protecting yourself from authoritarian governments to opting out of the surveillance capitalism of Google, Facebook, and data brokers.

Talking to my roommate about grocery shopping is benign to us, but it‚Äôs literally gold to data brokers, and I‚Äôd rather that conversation be private than spied on so I can be shown targeted ads in relation to it.

Avitus:

Default end-to-end encryption isn‚Äôt ‚ÄúBig Brother‚Äù. It‚Äôs actually the opposite: keeping users safe from Big Brother.

I think it wasn‚Äôt meant to be Orwellian Big Brother here but something like ‚Äúdon‚Äôt be annoying older brother who tells me how I should be using the app‚Äù. But as always, I might be wrong.

posts.name: Wyatt Childers
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm not sure what this is actually advocating for.

The current model is already end-to-end encrypted and the current model also allows for full message synchronization (as of a few months ago).

Once end-to-end encrypted cloud backups are implemented, presumably users will gain additional ease of use benefits (restore from cloud on desktop, mobile, tablet, etc).

posts.name: Drakelien
posts.cooked: Full message synchronisation, for desk top and IPad (Apple), but not for tablet with operating system android. Please correct me when I am wrong.

posts.name: Wyatt Childers
posts.cooked:
I think that‚Äôs just an issue of Signal Android not having proper tablet support (?)

EDIT: Actually no idea, I don‚Äôt have an Android tablet to test with and the link was out of date; I‚Äôm seeing conflicting information.

Android tablets can not be linked, so there is no synchronization. Yes, messages can be synchronized completely now and media up to 45 days old too. I think even older media can be selectively synchronized, but it has do be done manually.

posts.name: Drakelien
posts.cooked: Thanks for the explaining, some misunderstanding on my part. I assumed synchronising being the way to see the complete chat, even when the device was turned off, but of course the device should be linked or be the primary device. So indeed my question was off topic.
BTW, from someone who cant stand acronyms, WTF does ‚ÄòRFE‚Äô mean?

presumably it‚Äôs not Request for Evidence [wp]

probably request for enhancement

posts.name: Martin Terra
posts.cooked: The way users currently shoot them on their foot is by opting to use ‚Äú(seemingly) more user firendly‚Äù alternatives.
With ‚Äúdual security mode‚Äù the actual security level will be the lowest one set amongst participants in a given chat. Oh boy .
